ground_truth_answer: Insurance valuations for jewelry serve different purposes depending on cover type. For replacement value coverage, insurers will typically replace lost or stolen jewelry based on current valuation, using quotes from their valuers to set up purchase orders at chosen jewelers. For present value coverage, settlements may be lower. Even with professional valuations, insurers like IAG require revaluation at claim time to establish current value. For unique items like antiques, if an acceptable replacement isn't available, insurers may settle for present value instead of replacement value. This aligns with scheduled property policies, which don't typically have automatic appreciation adjustments, meaning the insured value remains static as stated in the original appraisal unless updated.
